study_duration: From down-regulation day (T1) to 3 days before pregnancy test (T3).

study_goal: The researchers examined whether mindfulness-based video interventions (PIRI and PPRS) could reduce prescription opioid misuse in individuals after a recent sexual assault.
results_summary: The PIRI video reduced prescription opioid misuse at 1.5 months post-assault for participants with prior sexual assault history, but no significant effects were found for the PPRS video or overall main effects.
population_specificity: Adolescent girls and women (n=154) recruited during a sexual assault medical forensic exam in an emergency department.
study_duration: Single session during the forensic exam, with follow-up at 1.5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) could effectively improve mindful eating and promote sustainable nutritional behaviors in a healthy adult student population.
results_summary: The MBI showed strong effects on mindful eating but limited effects on sustainable nutritional behaviors, which were only evident in qualitative data as changes in attitudes and intentions. Follow-up results suggested a slower process for adopting sustainable food choices.
population_specificity: Healthy adult students (n = 76/n = 11).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy and sustained effects of an 8-week mindfulness meditation mobile app (Calm) on stress, mindfulness, and self-compassion in college students with elevated stress, while also exploring its impact on health behaviors and feasibility.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in stress, mindfulness, and self-compassion in the intervention group compared to controls, with effects persisting at follow-up. Moderate to large effect sizes were observed, and the app was deemed acceptable and helpful by most participants, though effects on other health behaviors were limited.
population_specificity: Full-time undergraduate college students (aged ≥18) with elevated stress (Perceived Stress Scale ≥14).
effective_dosage: At least 10 minutes of meditation per day using the Calm app.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single ketamine infusion could improve treatment outcomes, including abstinence and relapse prevention, in cocaine-dependent adults engaged in mindfulness-based relapse prevention.
results_summary: The ketamine group showed significantly higher abstinence rates (48.2% vs. 10.7%) and a 53% lower likelihood of relapse compared to the control group, along with a 58.1% reduction in craving scores. Infusions were well tolerated with no adverse events leading to study removal.
population_specificity: Cocaine-dependent adults engaged in mindfulness-based relapse prevention.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mg/kg intravenous ketamine infusion over 40 minutes.
study_duration: 5-day inpatient stay with a 5-week mindfulness-based relapse prevention course.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and effectiveness of a text messaging program (iQuit Mindfully) as an adjunct to in-person Mindfulness-Based Addiction Treatment (MBAT) for smoking cessation, particularly among low-income smokers.
results_summary: The study found high retention (76% at end of treatment, 89% at 1-month follow-up) and engagement (88% read most texts, 89% interacted with texts), with positive participant ratings (average 8.4/10 for recommending the program). Biochemically confirmed smoking cessation rates were 22% at end of treatment and 19% at 1-month follow-up, with no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Low-income smokers (61% with annual household income ≤$30,000), predominantly African American (70%).
effective_dosage: 8 weekly therapist-led group counseling sessions, nicotine patches, and self-help materials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on physiological and psychological criteria in a nonselective sample of police officers and whether effectiveness depends on personality traits and perceived social norms.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study investigates the effects of MBIs in a nonselective sample, suggesting an exploration of efficacy in a new context.
population_specificity: Police officers in an agentic and male-oriented culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a 2-week adapted mindfulness meditation protocol for chronic stroke survivors and explore its preliminary effects on spasticity and quality of life.
results_summary: Participants reported meditating an average of 12.5 days out of 15, with no adverse effects. Preliminary analyses showed statistically significant improvements in spasticity, though qualitative data was limited to 7 out of 10 participants.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with spasticity.
effective_dosage: Short mindfulness meditation recordings (adapted from Jon Kabat-Zinn's Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction course), frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a combined MSDE intervention, including mindfulness-based psychotherapy, on abstinence and mental health in male heroin users.
results_summary: The MSDE intervention significantly improved contemplation for abstinence, reduced obsessive-compulsive drug use, depression, and aggression, and led to higher abstinence and retention rates compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Male heroin users in a Chinese drug rehabilitation center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate caregivers' experiences with a blended psychosocial support program, including mindfulness exercises, and to understand its mechanisms of impact.
results_summary: Caregivers found the program beneficial overall but had ambivalent reactions to mindfulness exercises and peer contact. The program helped them gain awareness of their situation, perceive control, accept negative emotions, and feel acknowledged.
population_specificity: Caregivers of patients with ALS or PMA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a mindfulness and acceptance-based self-help approach for treating social anxiety.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in social anxiety, self-compassion, mindfulness, acceptance, and depression, with effect sizes ranging from .74 to .79. A unidirectional model showed that increases in acceptance led to subsequent decreases in social anxiety.
population_specificity: Individuals seeking help for social anxiety or shyness recruited from the community (N = 117 initially, expanded to 93 for additional analyses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive behavioral therapy as a treatment for global sexual dysfunction in women, particularly postmenopausal women and those undergoing cancer treatment or taking antidepressants.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based cognitive behavioral therapy is a supported treatment option for women with global sexual dysfunction, particularly in postmenopausal women and those with comorbidities like cancer or antidepressant use. Benefits were noted across multiple phases of sexual function rather than being limited to a single phase.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women, women treated for breast or gynecologic cancer, and women taking antidepressants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the effectiveness of Pacifica, a mindfulness-based app, in reducing self-reported symptoms of stress, anxiety, and depression.
results_summary: Participants using Pacifica showed significant reductions in depression, anxiety, and stress, with sustained improvements linked to completing thought record exercises. Those on psychiatric medications benefited less from the app.
population_specificity: 500 adults with mild-to-moderate anxiety or depression.
interactions: Reduced efficacy for participants taking psychiatric medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an online mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) could effectively reduce depression severity and improve secondary outcomes like anxiety, fatigue, pain, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial assessing the efficacy of an online MBI for PwMS, with primary and secondary outcomes measured pre- and post-treatment, and at three- and six-month follow-ups. The abstract does not report specific results but highlights the potential of MBIs based on prior meta-analyses and the novelty of online delivery for this population.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up assessments at three and six months post-treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent research on psychological interventions, including mindfulness, for traumatic brain injury survivors.
results_summary: The study noted that mindfulness, along with other therapies like CBT, has been proposed for treating behavioral and emotional disturbances, but more literature on its effectiveness is expected in the future.
population_specificity: Primarily adult traumatic brain injury survivors, with limited representation from pediatric and Latin American populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map available evidence on the efficacy of mind-body practices, including mindfulness, in people living with HIV.
results_summary: Mindfulness, along with a combination of relaxation techniques and cognitive behavioral strategies, showed encouraging results in reducing physical and psychological symptoms and improving quality of life and health in people living with HIV. However, more rigorous studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: People living with HIV

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) for improving mental well-being (anxiety, depression, stress) in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: MBIs were found effective at improving mental well-being in PwMS, with an overall standardized mean difference of 0.40 (p<0.01), indicating a moderate effect size. More research is needed on optimal delivery methods, cost-effectiveness, and comparative-effectiveness.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of occupational e-mental health interventions, including mindfulness, on various mental health outcomes and identify potential moderators of treatment effects.
results_summary: The study found a small treatment effect on mindfulness (Hedges' g=0.42), indicating modest but statistically significant improvements. The pooled effect was consistent with other mental health areas but smaller than effects observed for stress, insomnia, and burnout.
population_specificity: Occupational e-mental health intervention participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a structured skills training group (SSTG) based on dialectical behaviour therapy (DBT) adapted for adolescents with ADHD, focusing on ADHD symptoms, functional impairment, quality of life, and mindfulness.
results_summary: The study protocol describes the adaptation of SSTG for adolescents with ADHD and outlines a randomized controlled trial (RCT) design to assess its efficacy, but specific results regarding mindfulness effects are not yet provided as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Adolescents (15-18 years) with a diagnosis of ADHD recruited from child and adolescent psychiatric outpatient units.
study_duration: Measures were conducted weekly during treatment, with assessments 2 weeks before, 2 weeks after, and 6 months after treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of Mindful Awareness in Body-oriented Therapy (MABT) as an adjunct to buprenorphine treatment for individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD).
results_summary: The MABT group showed increased interoceptive awareness skills compared to the control group, with positive feedback on intervention satisfaction and perceived benefits. Recruitment and retention were feasible, indicating preliminary support for a larger study.
population_specificity: Individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD) receiving buprenorphine treatment in an urban community medical center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine interventions implemented to prevent burnout and depression during intern year, focusing on the effectiveness of mindfulness practices.
results_summary: Most studies showed a modest reduction in depression and burnout with mindfulness interventions, but many lacked sufficient statistical power to reach significant conclusions. More research is needed for generalizable findings.
population_specificity: Medical interns and residents.

study_goal: To examine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on psychological and physiological measures in adults with cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: MBIs improved psychological outcomes (anxiety, depression, distress, and perceived stress) and reduced systolic blood pressure, but not diastolic blood pressure, compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adults with CVD or who had experienced a cardiac event (N = 1,476; mean age = 56 years; 40% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the limited efficacy of a 12-week online yoga intervention on symptom burden and quality of life in MPN patients and assess the feasibility of remotely collecting inflammatory biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found small to moderate effects of online yoga on sleep disturbance, pain intensity, anxiety, and depression, with a notable decrease in TNF-α levels. Remote blood collection was deemed feasible, though larger trials are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of integrating Mindfulness-Oriented Recovery Enhancement (MORE) with exercise and nutrition counseling for obese cancer survivors and to explore its potential therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that MORE significantly improved interoceptive awareness, savoring, and natural reward responsiveness while reducing maladaptive eating behaviors and food attentional bias, which was linked to decreased waist-to-hip ratio.
population_specificity: Female overweight and obese cancer survivors (mean age 57.92, 88% with breast cancer history, 96% white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Relapse Prevention (MBRP) in reducing craving and improving quality of life and psychological flexibility in French patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD).
results_summary: Participants showed significant reductions in craving, alcohol use, depression, and anxiety, along with increased mindfulness and psychological flexibility at 6 months. Most participants incorporated mindfulness into daily life, with sustained practice rates of 49-69% for formal and 64-80% for informal practice at follow-up.
population_specificity: Adult outpatients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) in France (n=52).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of MBCT, DBT, and PPT on perceived stress and quality of life in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: MBCT significantly reduced perceived stress compared to other groups, while PPT showed higher quality of life improvements. The study found statistically significant differences in outcomes between the intervention groups.
population_specificity: Patients with IBS diagnosed using Rome-IV criteria (46 female, 27 male).
effective_dosage: 8 group sessions (specific duration per session not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which psychological therapies, including mindfulness-based therapies, could concurrently address PTSD and pain-related symptoms in adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed moderate effectiveness in reducing PTSD severity but nonsignificant effects on pain intensity and interference. Mindfulness-based therapies were among the interventions evaluated, but their specific efficacy was not isolated in the results.
population_specificity: Adults with co-occurring PTSD and pain-related symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a modified Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) on stress reduction in family caregivers of people with dementia.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a randomized controlled trial to compare modified MBCT with a control group receiving social interaction and routine education, measuring stress and secondary outcomes post-intervention and at 6-month follow-up. The abstract suggests MBCT is effective for stress reduction in other populations, but results for caregivers of dementia patients are pending.
population_specificity: Family caregivers of community-dwelling people with dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of school-based psychological interventions, including Mindfulness, in improving student mental health and well-being and preventing mental illness.
results_summary: The meta-review found that Mindfulness interventions were generally effective, with effect sizes ranging from small to large, though the authors highlighted the need for additional high-quality trials.
population_specificity: Students in school settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of a structured mindfulness group intervention in improving emotional self-regulation in children with ADHD.
results_summary: Children with ADHD who received mindfulness-based group therapy showed reduced deficient emotional self-regulation (DESR), particularly in the dysregulation profile measured by the CBCL. However, no significant changes were observed in children with combined-type ADHD.
population_specificity: Children aged 7-12 years with ADHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of integrative body-mind-spirit (I-BMS) practices, including mindfulness, for alleviating symptoms and improving outcomes in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions, among other I-BMS practices, showed medium to large effect sizes in reducing symptoms, anxiety, and stress, while improving insight, well-being, and social/occupational functioning, as well as reducing re-hospitalization rates.
population_specificity: Patients with schizophrenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a 7-week online mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) tailored to reduce stress in emergency medical dispatchers (EMDs).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in stress for the intervention group compared to controls, both post-intervention and at 3-month follow-up. While mindfulness scores did not differ between groups, increases in mindfulness were correlated with greater stress reductions across all participants.
population_specificity: Active-duty emergency medical dispatchers (EMDs) from the USA and Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mindfulness training (DBT-M) on BPD symptomatology and DMN activity compared to a control intervention (DBT-IE).
results_summary: Both groups improved in BPD symptoms, but no between-group differences in DMN activation were found. The DBT-M group showed higher deactivation in occipital regions compared to controls.
population_specificity: 65 individuals with borderline personality disorder (BPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based therapies (MBTs) in reducing psychological distress in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), Parkinson's disease (PD), and Huntington's disease (HD).
results_summary: The study found that CBT and MBTs had a small to moderate effect (effect sizes of 0.51 and 0.36) in reducing psychological distress in MS and PD patients, but no RCTs were available for HD populations. The overall quality of included studies was low, with considerable heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS), Parkinson's disease (PD), and Huntington's disease (HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore potential benefits of modified mindfulness-based stress reduction (modMBSR) on stress, cognition, and performance in first-year surgery residents.
results_summary: The study found that modMBSR showed potential benefits in reducing perceived stress, improving mindfulness, and enhancing working memory and cognitive control, with some improvements in motor skill performance. However, burnout increased similarly in both groups. Neuroimaging revealed unique postintervention activity in brain areas linked to executive function and self-awareness.
population_specificity: Postgraduate year 1 (PGY-1) surgery residents at an academic medical center.
effective_dosage: Weekly 2-hour modMBSR classes and 20 minutes of daily home practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on VR in psychotherapy, particularly its relevance to mindfulness and sexual dysfunction treatment.
results_summary: The study found that VR exposure-based therapy is empirically validated for anxiety disorders, and emerging research suggests potential benefits of combining VR and mindfulness for chronic pain treatment, though experimental research on SDs is lacking.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how dopamine regulation, including interventions like mindfulness, could impact vulnerability or resilience to PTSD.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, alongside other pro-dopamine regulation interventions, may help achieve dopamine homeostasis, potentially aiding in PTSD management. However, specific efficacy data on mindfulness alone is not detailed.
population_specificity: Military enlistees and individuals at risk of PTSD or reward deficiency disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acceptance skills training is a necessary active ingredient in mindfulness interventions for stress reduction.
results_summary: The study found that participants who received both monitoring and acceptance training (MA) showed increased nonjudgment and reduced stress compared to those who received only monitoring training (MO) or no treatment (NT). These results suggest that acceptance skills are critical for the stress-reduction benefits of mindfulness interventions.
population_specificity: Stressed community adults

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) combined with music therapy (MT) on clinical symptoms (pain, anxiety, sleep quality) in patients with osteosarcoma.
results_summary: The combined MBSR/MT intervention significantly reduced pain and anxiety scores and improved sleep quality in osteosarcoma patients compared to the control group. The study demonstrated clinically meaningful benefits from the 8-week intervention.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with osteosarcoma (n=101, randomized into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of MBSR and MT psychotherapy (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility/acceptability of a mindfulness-based intervention for preventing excess weight gain in adolescents at-risk and to pilot test its efficacy in improving food reward sensitivity, stress-eating, executive function, and BMI/adiposity.
results_summary: The mindfulness intervention was feasible and acceptable, with above-average ratings. It showed lower food reward sensitivity compared to health education but no significant differences in BMI/adiposity outcomes.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 12-17 at-risk for excess weight gain (BMI ≥70th percentile or parental obesity history).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of integrated rehabilitation treatments combining exercise and psychological therapies, including mindfulness, on physical activity and quality of life in patients with painful diabetic neuropathy (PDN).
results_summary: The study found moderate effects of mindfulness meditation on quality of life and mindfulness-based stress reduction on function, health-related quality of life, pain catastrophizing, and depression in PDN patients. However, no studies directly combined exercise and psychological interventions, and overall evidence was limited.
population_specificity: Patients with painful diabetic neuropathy (PDN), aged >18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the features of successful educational interventions, including mindfulness-type approaches, for stress management among practicing doctors.
results_summary: The review identified mindfulness-type interventions as one of three broad categories that showed positive outcomes in stress management, though the effectiveness varied by context such as medical specialty and healthcare systems.
population_specificity: Practicing doctors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in reducing ADHD symptoms and improving related outcomes in adults.
results_summary: All included studies showed improvement in ADHD symptoms, with additional benefits in executive function and emotion regulation, though methodological biases and study quality limitations were noted.
population_specificity: Adults with ADHD (mean age 35.1 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which third-wave therapies, including mindfulness, have been adapted for adults with intellectual disabilities and whether they produced positive outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that third-wave therapies, including mindfulness-based approaches, improved mental health symptoms for some participants and enhanced challenging/offending behavior, smoking cessation, and mindfulness/acceptance skills for most. However, the findings should be interpreted cautiously due to low methodological quality.
population_specificity: Adults with intellectual disabilities

study_goal: To assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a mobile/online-based mindfulness intervention for reducing distress and improving quality of life in cancer patients and their caregivers.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life for patients and increased mindfulness for caregivers in the intervention group compared to controls. Retention and adherence rates were acceptable, with participants appreciating the convenience and skills gained from the program.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy and their informal caregivers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) with cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) in treating provoked vestibulodynia (PVD), particularly focusing on self-reported pain during vaginal penetration and psychological endpoints.
results_summary: MBCT showed greater improvements in self-reported pain during vaginal penetration compared to CBT, while both therapies led to similar significant improvements in other endpoints (e.g., pain catastrophizing, sexual function) with benefits maintained at 6 months.
population_specificity: 130 women with clinically diagnosed provoked vestibulodynia (PVD), mean ages 31.2 (CBT group) and 33.7 (MBCT group).
study_duration: Immediate post-treatment and 6-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of mindfulness-based meditation as a treatment for depression and anxiety disorders, both as monotherapy and adjunctive therapy.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based meditation showed positive effects on depression, with benefits lasting six months or more. While evidence for anxiety disorders was less consistent, it supported adjunctive use, with no apparent negative effects reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression or anxiety disorders, including treatment-resistant depression, unipolar depression, posttraumatic stress disorder, and panic disorder.
study_duration: Effects observed for six months or more (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mindfulness-augmented version of the "Trampoline" programme in improving adaptive stress-coping strategies and reducing problem behaviors in children from substance-involved families.
results_summary: The study expects larger effects on adaptive stress-coping strategies, internalising and externalising problem behaviors, and distress due to parental substance use compared to the standard programme. It also investigates the feasibility of mindfulness-based interventions in psychiatric and youth welfare settings.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-12 from substance-involved families receiving non-substance-specific care in psychiatric or youth welfare services.
effective_dosage: Mindfulness components practiced for 30 minutes in each validated "Trampoline" module.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of integrating mindfulness and other well-being programs into school-based interventions for youth with depressive disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, alongside positive psychology and depression education, can be effective in addressing depressive symptoms and promoting well-being in school settings. However, specific efficacy data for mindfulness alone are not detailed.
population_specificity: Youth (teens) with depressive disorders in school settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness training among various cognitive and behavioral interventions for promoting self-control.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness training was not consistently effective in increasing self-control, unlike other interventions reviewed. The abstract suggests that most interventions were domain-specific, but mindfulness did not demonstrate significant or lasting effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of interventions for self-control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence supporting the use of complementary and alternative treatments, including mindfulness, for neuropathy and neuropathic pain.
results_summary: The study found encouraging evidence for mindfulness-based practices in treating neuropathic pain, suggesting potential benefits as part of a broader intervention strategy.
population_specificity: Patients with neuropathy and neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and potential effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) as a therapy for moderate-to-severe episodic migraine.
results_summary: The study is a pilot trial, so definitive results are not yet available, but MBSR has shown promising results in small case studies and pilot studies for migraine therapy. The feasibility outcomes include recruitment ability, adherence to MBSR, and measurement of outcomes using headache diaries and questionnaires.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate-to-severe episodic migraine in Northern California.
effective_dosage: 8-week community-based MBSR class (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an online group Mindfulness-Based Cancer Recovery (MBCR) program delivered during chemotherapy could reduce fatigue (primary outcome) and improve secondary symptoms like sleep disturbance, pain, and quality of life.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results, but the study design suggests it will evaluate the efficacy of MBCR in reducing fatigue and other symptoms post-chemotherapy, with potential implications for adjunctive symptom management during treatment.
population_specificity: Breast or colorectal cancer patients undergoing common chemotherapy regimens in Calgary, Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the theoretic model, structure, and preliminary evidence for emerging treatments in eating disorders, including mindfulness-based approaches.
results_summary: The abstract mentions preliminary evidence supporting the use of mindfulness in eating disorder treatments, alongside other therapies, but does not provide specific outcomes or statistical results for mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with eating disorders (specific subtype not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers sought to link the clinical presentation of distress disorders to disruptions in neural networks and explore how mindfulness meditation might ameliorate these conditions through increases in decentering.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness-based interventions reliably increase decentering, which may help improve distress disorders by enhancing meta-awareness, disidentification from internal experience, and reducing reactivity to thought content. The abstract proposes a neurobehavioral account for these effects but does not provide specific clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not mention a specific study population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 6-week mindfulness training program on mental health outcomes among male Chinese prisoners and explore differences between long-term and short-term prisoners.
results_summary: The mindfulness training group showed significant improvement in mindfulness levels compared to the waitlist control group. Other outcomes (anxiety, depression, aggression, sleep quality, mood states, total mood disturbance, and perceived stress) were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Male Chinese prisoners (83 participants, 39 in mindfulness group, 44 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) to treatment as usual (TAU) improves symptomatic and functional outcomes in adults with bipolar disorder compared to TAU alone.
results_summary: The study will evaluate the effectiveness of MBCT on depressive symptoms, manic symptoms, anxiety, relapse rates, functioning, and cost-effectiveness, but specific results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with bipolar type I and type II disorder.
study_duration: Assessments conducted up to 15 months follow-up, but intervention duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness training (MT) reduces posterior cingulate cortex (PCC) reactivity to smoking cues and whether changes in PCC activity predict smoking outcomes.
results_summary: The MT group showed a significant correlation between reduced PCC reactivity to smoking cues and decreased cigarette consumption, particularly in women. No such association was found in the control group, and no group-level effects were observed for PCC or cigarette reduction.
population_specificity: Individuals who smoke (n=67, with 33 in the MT group and 34 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore self-management strategies, including mindfulness, for problem gambling recovery in adults.
results_summary: The study identified mindfulness as one of the less common self-management strategies (8% of reviewed articles), but did not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes for mindfulness in problem gambling recovery.
population_specificity: Adults (18+) with problem gambling confirmed by validated diagnostic or screening tools.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of mindfulness- and acceptance-based interventions in improving sexual satisfaction among prostate cancer survivors.
results_summary: Current pharmacologic interventions for sexual difficulties in prostate cancer survivors are insufficient, and existing psychological interventions lack methodological consistency. Preliminary evidence suggests mindfulness may improve men's sexual functioning by shifting focus from performance to sensations.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer survivors (and their partners)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acceptability and preliminary efficacy of CBCT (a mindfulness and compassion-based intervention) compared to cancer health education in improving depressive symptoms and other HRQOL domains in cancer survivors and their informal caregivers.
results_summary: The study is in progress, so definitive results are not yet available, but the goal is to assess effect sizes for depressive symptoms, HRQOL domains, biomarkers of inflammation, cortisol rhythm, and healthcare utilization outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (solid tumor, post-primary treatment) and their informal caregivers, with at least one dyad member experiencing mild depressive symptoms or anxiety.
effective_dosage: 8-week group intervention (CBCT or CHE), frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapies (MBTs) for treating insomnia and sleep disturbance, review existing literature, and conduct a meta-analysis comparing MBTs with control groups.
results_summary: The study presents a psychological process model linking mindfulness to sleep, reviews trials of MBTs for sleep issues, and finds through meta-analysis that MBTs show promise in improving insomnia and sleep disturbance compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Individuals with insomnia and general sleep disturbance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a brief mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) on persistent pain patients and assess the feasibility of conducting a definitive RCT.
results_summary: The study found no significant immediate effects of the MBI but reported positive effects for intervention 'usefulness' at 1 week and pain self-efficacy at 1 month compared to the control group. Recruitment was feasible, but retention strategies were needed.
population_specificity: Persistent pain patients
effective_dosage: 15-minute mindfulness body-scan audio, used independently over 1 month

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-session professional development course on trauma awareness improved the quality of preschool teachers' relationships with children in their classrooms.
results_summary: The course did not significantly reduce teacher-children conflict scores or improve secondary relational outcomes, but qualitative feedback from teachers suggested potential improvements in relationship quality and relational capacities.
population_specificity: Preschool teachers (96.9% women, 60.4% aged 40+) working with 3- and 4-year-old children from low-income households in Philadelphia.
